column4: シャドリナ　エレナ
column15: 初級レベル（入門・導入）
column23:
Аникина М.Н. Лестница. Учебник по русскому языку для начинающих. М., “Русский язык. Курсы”, 2015. 464 c. pap.
ISBN 9785883373670 R139261
(for English-speaking students, +MP3 CD, 5 hours 30 minutes, levels 0-A2)
アニーキナ　ステップ　初心者のためのロシア語教科書（ゼロから基礎レベルまで）（CD付）

This textbook by Anikina can be found at Russian language literature shop called "Nauka" near to Jimboucho Station or ordered online http://www.naukajapan.jp/detail.php?id=139261

The SILS library has a reserve copy of the textbook.

column4: 布袋　敏博／近藤　友梨
column15: 初級レベル（入門・導入）
column23:
Let’s study Korean (work edited by Toshihiro HOTEI, Wonsop SHIM, Mikang LEE; Aruku)
『学ぼう 韓国・朝鮮語』（布袋敏博・沈元燮・李美江共著、アルク刊）
column24:
[{"name"=>"その他", "rate"=>"100％", "detail"=>"Grading is based on the comprehensive evaluation which includes attendance, frequency of tardy, completion of the assignments, general attitude in the class, mid-term, and final examination. When and if absence becomes conspicuous, names will be deleted from the roster. Absence caused by illness or job hunting would be exempted the attendance policy.

The course is team taught by two faculty members. Students are obliged to attend classes taught by both faculty members. When and if students only attend one class session taught by a faculty member and neglect to attend the other class, students would not receive any credit. Even if a student receives a passing grade from the final examination, neglecting to attend both classes taught by both faculty members would be nullified.

Students at SILS tend to be late and do not seem to carefully prepare for the class. Each student shall be responsible for his/her general study habit such as reviewing and following the curriculum and organize study materials. Moreover, each student should not forget to bring required textbooks."}]

column4: 安　垠姫／神谷　丹路
column15: 初級レベル（入門・導入）
column23:
Let’s study Korean (work edited by Toshihiro HOTEI, Wonsop SHIM, Mikang LEE; Aruku)
『学ぼう 韓国・朝鮮語』（布袋敏博・沈元燮・李美江共著、アルク刊）
column24:
[{"name"=>"その他", "rate"=>"100％", "detail"=>"Grading is based on the comprehensive evaluation which includes attendance, frequency of tardy, completion of the assignments, general attitude in the class, mid-term, and final examination. When and if absence becomes conspicuous, names will be deleted from the roster. Absence caused by illness or job hunting would be exempted the attendance policy.

The course is team taught by two faculty members. Students are obliged to attend classes taught by both faculty members. When and if students only attend one class session taught by a faculty member and neglect to attend the other class, students would not receive any credit. Even if a student receives a passing grade from the final examination, neglecting to attend both classes taught by both faculty members would be nullified.

Students at SILS tend to be late and do not seem to carefully prepare for the class. Each student shall be responsible for his/her general study habit such as reviewing and following the curriculum and organize study materials. Moreover, each student should not forget to bring required textbooks."}]

column4: ドボルザーク　グレッグ
column15: 中級レベル（発展・応用）
column23:
As this is a recent addition to the courses offered at Waseda School of International Liberal Studies, we are still negotiating the procurement of textbooks with the Waseda Co-op Bookstore to ensure that they will be affordable and readily available for the number of students enrolled in this class. In principle, many of your course materials will be provided via online download as PDFs that should take roughly 2-4 hours to read. However, one or two required books MAY be assigned. You will be advised of these details on the first day of class.

In addition to readings, we will view films and video programs in class, many of which are hard to obtain. You will be responsible for coming to class to view these.

Separate from this, a number of optional readings, films, and other resources will be recommended for students. Some of these materials will be in Japanese and in other languages, accounting for the diversity of the SILS student body.

column4: 吉本　光宏
column13: 表現（美術／映像／演劇／音楽／芸能／文学／メディア論）
column15: 中級レベル（発展・応用）
column23:
We are reading only selected chapters or sections from the following books:

--Louis Althusser, On the Reproduction of Capitalism: Ideology and Ideological State Apparatuses (Verso, 2014).
--Roland Barthes, “Myth Today,” in Mythologies
--Alfie Bown, The PlayStation Dreamworld (Polity, 2017)
--Michael Buckland, Information and Society (MIT Press, 2017)
--Brian Housand, Fighting Fake News!: Teaching Critical Thinking and Media Literacy in a Digital Age (Prufrock Press, 2018)
--Jaron Lanier, Ten Arguments for Deleting Your Social Media Accounts Right Now (Henry Holt, 2018)
--Lee McIntyre, Post-Truth (MIT Press, 2018)
--Brian McNair, Fake News: Falsehood, Fabrication and Fantasy in Journalism (Routledge, 2018)
--Angela Nagle, Kill All Normies: Online Culture Wars from Tumblr and 4chan to the Alt-right and Trump. (Zero Books, 2017)
--Cathy O’Neil, Weapons of Mass Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy (Penguin, 2017)
--Brian L. Ott and Robert L. Mack, Critical Media Studies: An Introduction, 2nd edition (Wiley Blackwell, 2014)
--Dominic Pettman, Infinite Distraction (Polity, 2016)
--Ferdinand de Saussure, Course in General Linguistics (Open Court, 1986)
--Douglas Spencer, The Architecture of Neoliberalism: How Contemporary Architecture Became an Instrument of Control and Compliance (Bloomsbury, 2016)

column4: ドボルザーク　グレッグ
column15: 上級レベル
column23: This course is primarily discussion-based and focused on students developing their own research techniques and topics; therefore, some of the material we read will be determined by class participants and the topics we choose together. This seminar does not have an assigned textbook; however, based on the topics we cover, teams of students or individuals may be assigned a particular book to read and report to the class. In principle, when assigned, most readings will be distributed in PDF form (or via link to online resources) on CourseN@vi, so you ought to be familiar with how to use this system. More information will be provided in the first weeks of class.

column4: 大平　章
column15: 上級レベル
column23:
No set text. A packet of required readings will be provided at the beginning of the course. See list below for suggested readings on reserve in the SILS library:

Carl Jung, Archetypes of the Collective Unconscious, trans. R.F.C.Hull, Princeton University Press, 1977; A Study of the Process of Individuation, trans. R.F.C.Hull, Princeton University Press, 1977.
Charles Dickens, Bleak House, Penguin, 1853.
David Lodge, The Art of Fiction, Penguin, 1992; The Novelist at the Crossroads, Ark Paperbacks, 1971; Working with Structuralism, Ark Paperbacks, 1981.
D.H.Lawrence, Selected Short Stories, ed. Brian Finney, Penguin, 1982（『D・H・ロレンス短編全集』（全五巻）、鉄村他編訳、大阪教育図書、2006）; Sons and Lovers, Penguin, 1992; The Rainbow, Penguin, 1989; Women in Love, Penguin, 1982; Psychoanalysis and the Unconscious, Penguin, 1980; Fantasia of the Unconscious, Penguin, 1980.
Emily Bronte, Wuthering Heights, Penguin, 1847.
Gaston Bachelard’s Selected Works about symbolism of earth, air, water and fire: Water and Dreams, Air and Dreams, Fragments of A Poetics of Fire, The Right to Dream, The Flame of a Candle, trans. Kenneth Haltman, The Dallas Institute Publications, 1990-2004.
Georg W. Groddeck, The Book of It, trans. V.M.E.Collins, Vision Press, 1979.
James Joyce, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, Penguin, 1916.
Jane Austen, Emma, Penguin, 1816.
Joseph Conrad, Heart of Darkness, Penguin, 1902.
Robin Gilmour, The Novel in the Victorian Age, London: Edward Arnold, 1986.
Sigmund Freud, The Interpretation of Dreams, Totem and Taboo, trans. James Scrachey, Standard Edition, 1953, 1955.
The Dictionary of English and American Literature, Kenkyusha, 1990.
Junichiro Tanizaki, The Makioka Sisters, trans. E.G.Seidensticker, Tuttle, 1957; The Diary of A Mad Old Man, trans. Howard Hibbett,Tuttle, 1967; A Portrait of Shunkin, trans. Howard Hibbett, Tuttle, 1967; In Praise of Shadows, trans. T.J. Harper and E.G.Seidensticker, Tuttle, 1977; Ashikari, trans. Edwin McClellan, Tuttle, 1980．
Malcolm Bradbury, The Modern World: Ten Great Writers, Penguin, 1989.
Thomas Hardy, Tess of the D’Ubervilles, Penguin, 1891.
Yukio Mishima, The Sea of Fertility (Vol1-4), Shin Chosha, 1970 (Spring Snow, The Temple of Dawn, Runaway Horses, The Decay of the Angel; trans. Michael Gallagher, E.D.Sauders and C.S.Seigle, E.G.Seidensticker, New York: Pocket Books, 1980).

Bruce Hood, The Self Illusion
Malcolm Gladwell, Blink
Daniel Bor, The Ravenous Brain
* You do not need to purchase these books if they are available in the library, but you must read at least one of these books before the end of the semester. Any format is acceptable.

column23: There is no formal textbook to be purchased. The texts of the three novels in questions are all out of copyright and can be downloaded in PDF format from the course webpage. However, students will need to have some form of copy available during class both for the weekly quizzes (which are “open-book” format) and for the following discussions.

Briones Matthew M. “ From “Jap Crow” to “Jim and Jane Crow” Black and Blue (and Yellow) in Chicago and the Bay Ares” Jim and Japanese Crow: A Cultural History of 1940s Interracial America. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2012, pp. 162-191.

Chan Sucheng. “ The International Context of Asian Emigration,” Asian Americans: An Interpretive History. New York: Twayne Publishers, 1991(selections).

Ichioka Yuji. “ The Making of Loyalty: The Case of Kazumaro Buddy Uno.” Amerasia Journal. Vol 23 No.3. 1997, pp.45-71.

Mae Ngai, “ The Architecture of Race in American Immigration Law: A Reexamination of the Immigration Act of 1924.” The Journal of American History, Vl 86. No1 (Jun., 1999), pp.67-92.

Okihiro, Gary. Cane Fires: The Anti-Japanese Movement in Hawaii, 1865-1945. Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 1991(selection).

Robinson, Greg. After Camp: Portraits in Midcentury Japanese American Life and Politics. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 2012 (selections).

Roger Daniels. “ The Coming of the Japanese and the Ant-Japanese Movement,” Asian America: Chinese and Japanese in the United States since 1850. Seattle and London: University of Washington Press, 1988. pp. 100-154.

Takaki Ronald. “ Raising Cane: The World of Plantation Hawaii, “ Strangers from a Different Shore: A History of Asian Americans. Boston: Little Brown and Company, 1989.pp.132-176.

———————.” Pacific Crossing: Seeking the Land of Money Trees.” A Different Mirror: A History of Multicultural America. Boston:Little, Brown and Company, 1993. pp.246-276.

column3: The Bible, the text and its legacy　01
column4: ドゥ　サン　シャマ　ロイス
column15: 中級レベル（発展・応用）
column23:
There is no proper textbook for this Course. We’ll use the here above Reference books.

You NEED to have a personal book of the Bible - it must be a scholarly (with footnotes) edition - An English edition plus an edition in your mother language is advisable. At least one copy must be a printed one. In English, NABRE is recommended.

You will probably also be really happy to have :
- A Pocket guide to the Bible, Scott Hahn, 80p. A6, $6.95, ISBN 978-1-59276-443-3

column3: Pacific Perspectives on Empire, War, and Globalization　51
column4: ドボルザーク　グレッグ
column15: 中級レベル（発展・応用）
column23:
For many of the readings throughout this course, you will be able to download your own copy in PDF format and print at home or read off your laptop or portable device. We will also use the following REQUIRED text for many readings and to provide a deeper context for the course. It will be available in the co-op bookstore and on reserve in the SILS reading room:


Matsuda, Matt. Pacific Worlds. Cambridge University Press, 2012.


Below are two more OPTIONAL books that will be on reserve but which I encourage you to purchase for further knowledge and reflection:

Hau’ofa, Epeli. We Are the Ocean. Honolulu: University of Hawai’i Press, 2008.
Poyer, Falgout, and Carucci. Memories of War. Honolulu: University of Hawai’i Press, 2007.
